doc.field: Federal Environment Minister warns Hesse's government

The Federal Environment Ministry has warned Hesse's state government against ordering a transport ban on radioactive fuel-elements. Any such decree would be against the law, according to a written statement by the federal ministry. The ministry's 10-point plan would already make sure no such transports could take place. And apart from that, ordering a ban on transports would be totally beyond the state of Hesse's competence
Nuclear Supervisory Council knew of nuclear contamination as early as 1990

Allegedly Hesses's Nuclear Supervisory Council had been informed of radioactive contamination as early as 1990, according to energy generator RWE. At the time, the Technical Supervisory Agency in Baden had pointed out that during transports of nuclear fuel-rods radioactivity had been above thresholds. Hesse's Environment Minister Hinze so far had always maintained that he had learned of radioactive contamination only recently
Controversy about SPD's candidate for Minister of Economics

The row over the SPD's candidate for Minister of Economics, Mr Stollmann, continues. Mr Stollmann admitted that he had been a member of the CDU until 1986, but the fact had slipped his memory. Mr Stollmann was criticised by the unions: deputy head of the Council of Trade Unions (DBG) Ms Engelen-Kefer, thought that Mr Stollmann's stand against a treaty for work was not acceptable: Mr Schroeder's team has to close ranks without any one member rocking the boat. The SPD's social expert, Mr Dressler, also was not too keen on Mr Stollmann becoming Minister of Economics.

The 3-day commemoration of the 50th anniversary of the airlift to Berlin has begun. Leading politicians thought the airlift was a buildingblock for German re-unification. Foreign Minister Kinkel declared that the Berlin Wall would not have come down in 1989 had Berlin not been kept alive by allied supply-planes during the blockade of land-based supply-routes.

Former PM of France, Mr Giscard d'Estaing, said there were grave deficiencies in German-French co-operation. He claimed, in an interview with the newspaper SAARBRUECKENER ZEITUNG, that mutual trust had gone out the door. Amongst other things this would have been due to growing German self-esteem. Germany would not rank friendship with France as high as they had used to in the past.
Viagra not to be paid for by public health-insurers

The new potency-booster Viagra will not be paid for by public health-insurers, according to doctors and health-insurers. There will be a final decision, once experts have been heard, in August. At the end of September, Viagra will become licensed as a drug. Federal Health Minister Seehofer wholeheartedly agreed.

Speaker of Parliament Suessmuth (Bundestagspraesidentin) fined right-wing extremist party DVU 549,000 marks, as they had broken the law about party finance. According to the law, donations of more than 20,000 marks have to be declared. The party had in fact declared a donation of 270,000 marks, but had not given the correct address of the donor. They had reasoned that his safety would have been compromised had they published his correct address. The DVU party said they would appeal against the fine.
Steffi Graf not in Wimbledon tennis tournament any more
Steffi Graf is not in Wimbledon tennis tournament any more, having lost against Belarus' Ms Svereva 4:6 and 5:7 in the third round.
